body: This seems (but I'm not totally sure) to only occur when I use the left/right cursor keys to edit a line.
Hum... the left/right things is purely handled by readline. I'm not sure there is much we can do.

I understand, but it is weird that it didn't occur previously.

I tested a few more things: it only occurs when I press and hold left or right cursor (not when I repeatedly hit it), and I can free it by doing Ctrl-e or Ctrl-a etc or repeatedly clicking in and out of the terminal (though this latter way is variably successful).

hum... could it be a repetition thing on OS X? or the emoji-pop-up-dialog ?
Terminal.app or iTerm ?

I have the same problem after upgrading to El Capitan, both in Terminal.app and in xterm. If I run ipython without --pylab (no OSX backend), the python command line freezes every now and then, but Ctrl+C causes keyboard interrupt and it recovers. With --pylab and matplotlib OSX backend enabled, Ctrl+C does nothing, only killing the process works (or I haven't had the patience to wait long enough).

For me it doesn't require any arrow keys, just normal writing (typically fast) does the trick.

So, for me it seems that there's a problem with the ipython command line (readline?) and it would somehow clash with some other event loop if OSX backend is active ... just guessing ...

I might have the same problem. If I press and hold any key (arrows or letters) the input freezes. Although if I hit CTRL+C the input unfreezes, I and can continue to type. The problem only happens if matplotlib is loaded (invoke with `$> ipython --matplotlib` or `%matplotlib` after loading). 

The problem seems related to the Keyboard -> Key Repeat setting in the System Preferences. I only experience the keyboard freeze using the two fastest settings. By setting to the third fastest, the problem goes way (see figure).

![key repeat](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/807640/13319042/26df4e06-dbbf-11e5-9151-63048949eedd.png)

I am running:
Python 3.5.1
IPython 4.0.1
Matplotlib 1.5.1
MacOS 10.11.3

Changing the repeat setting didn't help for me.

But meanwhile I have noticed that even with --pylab when the command line freezes, hitting Ctrl-C followed by Enter works. So, now I don't need to kill the whole ipython session anymore and can actually work somehow (although it is still really annoying).

I've been having the same issue for a couple weeks now. I am always able to unlock it by hitting `<CTRL-C>` then `<enter>`. Whatever had been displayed before is in the history, so I can get back to where I was with `<up>`, but my session is littered with:

```
In [56]: xy =

KeyboardInterrupt

In [56]: xy = vor.points

In [57]: from scipy.spa
scipy.spacing  scipy.sparse   scipy.spatial

In [57]: from scipy.spatial import

KeyboardInterrupt

In [57]: from scipy.spatial import Co

KeyboardInterrupt

In [57]: from scipy.spatial import ConvexHull
```

So far, this is all I can gather:
1. Problem occurs if I run `ipython --pylab` or if I run `ipython` then later run `%matplotlib`, but so far I think not otherwise.
2. When it does occur, I can always free the interface and get the prompt back with `<CTRL-C><enter>`, but nothing else has worked. I tried other suggestions from this issue page, but `<CTRL-A>` and `<CTRL-E>` do not work. Waiting (for a few minutes) and clicking in and out of the terminal do not work.
3. It happens without using arrow keys, just alphanumeric keys are sufficient. However, it seems to only happen when I'm typing the start of something defined. That is, if I jam keys randomly, it is fine, but if I type `np` it can freeze. This is not so certain, and hard to test since the freezing is inconsistent. It can happen when hitting `<Tab>` as well, which is especially annoying, since I first think `<Tab>` is doing nothing because I've misspelled something so no completion exists, but it turns out it's frozen, so I have to hit `<CTRL-C><enter><up>`, then `<Tab>` works.
4. My keyboard repeat rate and delay are both set to the fastest setting. However, holding any keys down or typing randomly really fast do not induce the problem. I also have the problem happen at the settings shown in @rrbarbosa 's image.

Here's all the information that I can think of to provide:

```
OS X El Capitan 10.11.3
iTerm2 Build 2.9.20160206
IPython 4.0.3
python 2.7.11
matplotlib 1.5.1 (backend 'MacOSX')
```

Just wanted to add my input as a OS X 10.11...I thought it was just me. I've been using Anaconda 2.4.0 Python 3.x for more than a year without ever seeing this problem. This week was the first time I started getting back into matplotlib, and every time I startup ipython, I run into it. Like @leewalsh, I'm only able to get out with Ctrl-C.

I'm running ipython without any flags. The hiccups happen as soon as I run the magic command, `%matplotlib`...the freezing will just hit as I'm in the middle of typing out a line of code.

``` sh
$ sw_vers
ProductName:    Mac OS X
ProductVersion: 10.11.3
BuildVersion:   15D21
```

``` py
>>> sys.version
# 3.5.1 |Anaconda 2.4.0 (x86_64)| (default, Dec  7 2015, 11:24:55) 
# [GCC 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5577)]


>>> platform.platform()
'Darwin-15.3.0-x86_64-i386-64bit'

>>> os.uname()
# posix.uname_result(sysname='Darwin', nodename='DN.Net', release='15.3.0', 
# version='Darwin Kernel Version 15.3.0: Thu Dec 10 18:40:58 PST 2015; 
# root:xnu-3248.30.4~1/RELEASE_X86_64', machine='x86_64')
```

@Carreau, lots of information has been provided since you tagged this as `needs-info`. I understand if nobody has had time to look into this, but can you clarify whether we still need more info? If so, what kind of info would be helpful? I am happy to dig further but I don't know where to look. Or maybe do you think it's a matplotlib problem, not ipython?

I can remove the `need-info`, but yes, here we really need to figure out why it does that. 
It might be a matplotlib event loop integration issue, but I'm not sure why. 

Has @tacaswell or @minrk seen that and have an idea ? I'm unfamiliar with the event loop code, so the answer might be obvious to one of them, but not for me.
The thing @leewalsh reports with strange inputs may be related to a bug in readline.  Try hitting `ctrl-g` to see if that helps?
And I have been seeing some lockups like this on linux but I do strange things (run IPython terminal inside of emacs) and have not spent any time to track it down further.
I experience the same problem on El Cap. It does seem to be an event loop issue; whenever the hang occurs, if I bring the Matplotlib plotting window into focus, that frees up the hang.

What @leewalsh listed above describes my experiences pretty accurately too. Just to add, I don't seem to have the freeze if I'm writing a string, i.e. have the quote (") open. So this might be some kind to lookup / auto-complete related thing. Second, it happens only with matplotlib, but I don't need to have a plot window open, or ever opened during the session (yet). Third, taking a long command line from history (up arrow) and then trying to traverse that left/right by holding down the arrow key freezes pretty constanty, but if I hit the key repeatedly if doesn't (typically) freeze.

I have the same problem in El Capitan. I found by:
- running `ctrl-Z` when IPython is unresponsive
- followed by `fg` to bring the process back to the foreground
- running `ctrl-C` followed by Enter to generate a `KeyboardInterrupt` exception

is the fastest way to getting back to the interactive prompt. However, IPython becomes unresponsive after a few minutes.
what matplotlib backends is everyone using?  This is starting to sound like issues with `PyOS_InputHook`
Using matplotlib backend: MacOSX
Can you reproduce this with qtagg?

Yep, me too…

> On Apr 28, 2016, at 5:55 PM, Lee Walsh notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Using matplotlib backend: MacOSX
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
I've been running ipython with Qt4Agg for a while now and there have been no freezes. So, for me it seems to be MacOSX specific problem.
I've been seeing that with using matplotlib backend Qt4Agg (running inside a docker container on OSX).
For what it's worth, this issue seems to have disappeared with the magnificent and glorioius `IPython 5.0`. I vote to close.

@leewalsh I won't have time in the next week to properly confirm this but given how abruptly this issue popped up for a specific group of users, I won't at all be surprised if it is obsoleted in 5.0. Thanks for checking it out!
Closing - we can reopen it if it turns out it wasn't completely fixed.
I'm having this problem after upgrading to IPython 6.0 on Yosemite. Since readline got upgraded I'm guessing the problem is there.
As we moved away from readline, I'd guess that you're seeing a similar but different problem.

Problem goes away with --pylab and with simple prompt. Does that help
narrow down the underlying problem?
